title: 200 followers problem
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/solvable/14a9147ed4.5be58a3a0e.iQGwng.png?width=250"}},{"type":"text","text":"
If distance between the two points on the fixed "},{"type":"text","text":"smooth","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" inclined plane on which the ball makes first and second collision can be represented as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Delta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sqrt{\Delta}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Details","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Collisions are perfectly elastic.
-surface of inclined plane is smooth. "}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"No air resistance."}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"h=25m,B=30^{\circ}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            "Eliminating the parameter of time from the classical expressions of x and y for a body in free fall, H(x)= -(2/150)x^2 +x/sqrt(3), and G(x)= -x/sqrt(3)." Once the point of intersection is found, use it as the distance on the bottom leg of the 30-60-90 right triangle and simply solve for the hypotenuse.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 200 Followers Problem
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(x)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a 5th degree monic polynomial such that : "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(1) = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(2) = 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(3) = 5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(4) = 13"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(5) = 34"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"then find the value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(f(6) + f(7) + f(8))"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This problem is original","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Method of differences:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{array}{ccccccccccccccc}
1 && 2 && 5 && 13 && 34 && 201 && 892 && 2850 \\
& 1 && 3 && 8 && 21 && 167 && 691 && 1958 & \\
&& 2 && 5 && 13 && 146 && 524 && 1267 && \\
&&& 3 && 8 && 133 && 378 && 743 &&& \\
&&&& 5 && 125 && 245 && 365 &&&& \\
&&&&& 120 && 120 && 120 &&&&& \end{array}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Because this is a fifth degree polynomial, all 5th differences are equal. Because it is monic, the 5th differences are equal to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5! = 120"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Solution: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"201 + 892 + 2850 = \boxed{3943}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Lu Chee Ket – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" I posted a solution using the Method of Differences. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Dev Sharma – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" There is one I know called Gregory-Newton interpolation formula using forward finite differences for finding range of x in between the given five points. Interpolation is an on the line prediction whereby regression is analytical scatters. Actually, an interpolation as shown in my solution force to find for f (6), f (7) and f (8) by presuming that they are also points on a stated Monic Quintic Polynomial. Otherwise, this prediction is not a good prediction sometime for given points with many bending compared to regression."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Can you show the Method of difference as a solution wished by people at here? "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Method of difference is a nice way and you can read it on Brilliant wiki

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Would it be 100% reliable or could it need some special coincidence using the method you mentioned?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 200 Followers Problem!

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A=200^2-200"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r^3-s^3=Ars"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Write "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r-s=n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n \in \mathbb{Z}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(s+n)^3-s^3=A(s+n)s"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", or
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(A-3n)s^2+(An-3n^2)s-n^3=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
According to quadratic formula, we get 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"s=-\frac{n}{2}\pm \frac{|n|}{2} \frac{\sqrt{(A+n)(A-3n)}}{A-3n}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Therefore, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(A+n)(A-3n)=k^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a non-negative integer. It follows that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"-A \le n  \le \lfloor A/3 \rfloor"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"200"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". In the equation "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(A+n)(A-3n)=k^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" look mod "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"-3n^2 \equiv k^2 \pmod{5}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Hence "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n \equiv k \equiv 0 \pmod{5}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", since a perfect square mod "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is congruent to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0, 1, 4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" only. If you divide both sides of the equation by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"25"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and look mod "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" again, then it comes out that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n \equiv k \equiv 0 \pmod{25}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In the equation "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(A+n)(A-3n)=k^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" look mod "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"-3n^2 \equiv k^2 \pmod{8}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Hence "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are both even, since a perfect square mod "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is congruent to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0, 1, 4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" only. If you divide both sides of the equation by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and look mod "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" again, then a similar argument gives "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n \equiv k \equiv 0 \pmod{4}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Now write "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n=4n'"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k=4k'"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and divide both sides of the equation by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"16"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to get "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(A/4+n')(A/4-3n')=k'^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Look mod "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4+4n'+5n'^2 \equiv k'^2 \pmod{8}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n'"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is odd, then LHS of this congruence is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" mod "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which is contradiction. Thus "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n'"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k'"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are both even and finally "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n \equiv k \equiv 0 \pmod{8}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus in total we have that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n \equiv k \equiv 0 \pmod{200}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Write "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n=200 N"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k=200 K"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to get"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(199+N)(199-3N)=K^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
For "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\color{#D61F06}N=-199"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\color{#D61F06}N=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" the LHS becomes a square. Then, for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N \not\equiv 0 \pmod {199}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" we have that"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d=\gcd(199+N, 199-3N) \mid 3(199+N)+199-3n=4\times 199"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"Hence "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d=1, 2, 4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"199+N=a^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"199-3N=b^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are co-prime odd positive integers. Hence "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3a^2+b^2=796"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Its easy to see that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a \le 15"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Checking "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=1, 3, 5, ..., 15"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", reveals that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=13, 15"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" make "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"796-3a^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" a perfect square. Thus we get two pairs: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\color{#3D99F6}(a, b)=(13, 17), (15, 11)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" that result in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\color{#D61F06}N=-30"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\color{#D61F06}N=26"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", respectively."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d=2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"199+N=2a^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"199-3N=2b^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are co-prime positive integers. It follows that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3a^2+b^2=398"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Its easy to see that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a \le 11"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Check that none of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a \le 11"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" make "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"398-3a^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" a perfect square."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d=4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"199+N=4a^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"199-3N=4b^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are co-prime positive integers. It follows that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3a^2+b^2=199"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Its easy to see that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a \le 7"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Checking "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a \le 7 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", reveals that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" makes "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"199-3a^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" a perfect square. Thus we get one pair: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\color{#3D99F6}(a, b)=(1, 14)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" that results in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\color{#D61F06}N=-198"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Finally we get "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" solutions for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n=200N"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", namely "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n=-39800, -39000, -6000, 0, 5200"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n=-39800"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" gives only "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"s=19900"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" gives "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which is a contradiction! Other values of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" give two different solutions for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"s"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus the total number of solutions for the original equation is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{7}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Notice that if "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(r, s)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a solution, then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(-s, -r)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a solution too. Thus I write four of the solutions to the original equation. 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(r, s)=(s+n, s)=\left(-19900, 19900 \right), \left(-\frac{126750}{7}, \frac{146250}{7} \right), \left(-\frac{12000}{17}, \frac{90000}{17} \right), \left( \frac{67600}{11}, \frac{10400}{11} \right)"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The equation becomes
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" r^3 - s^3 \; =\; N(N-1)rs "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N=200"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and we want "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r = s+n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for some integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{aligned}
3s^2n + 3sn^2 + n^3 & =  N(N-1)(s^2 + sn) \\
\big[N(N-1) - 3n\big]s^2 + n\big[N(N-1) - 3n\big]s - n^3 & = 0 
\end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
and so
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
s \; = \; -\tfrac12n \pm \frac{n}{2\big[N(N-1) - 3n\big]}\sqrt{\big(N(N-1)-3n\big)\big(N(N-1) + n\big)} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Thus "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"-N(N-1) \le n < \tfrac13N(N-1)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\big(N(N-1) - 3n\big)\big(N(N-1) + n\big)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" must be a perfect square."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Simple calculations with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N=200"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" shows  that there are only "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" values of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for which this is true: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"-39800, -39000, -6000, 0, 5200"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"When "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n=-39800"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the only value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"s"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"19900"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". When "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the only value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"s"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and this is not a permitted solution of the original equation. The other three values of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" each yield two values of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"s"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and so there are a total of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{7}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" solutions."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Mark Hennings – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" On second viewing, I discovered that my work (without using Mark's Euclidean domain thingy technique, because I haven't mastered it yet!!) still requires plenty of trial and error. But I did try to minimize the amount of trials needed. Here's my failed attempt:"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"blockquote","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"From what I've written, we find to find non-negative integer solutions to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c^2 + 12m^2 = 25344640000"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Consider modulo 4, we can see that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c^2 \bmod 4= 0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus, let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c = 2c_1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m =m_1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (for consistency sake). Then the equation simplifies to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" c_1 ^2 + 3m_1 ^2 =6336160000 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Consider modulo 5. The quadratic residues of 5 are 0,1 and 4. Since RHS is divisible by 5, then so does LHS. Thus "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c_1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m_1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" must be divisible by 5. Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c_1 = 5c_2, m_1 = 5m_2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". The equation simplifies to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c_2^2 + 3 m_2 ^2 = 253446400"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Repeat the process again: Consider modulo 5. Since RHS is divisible by 5, then so does LHS. Thus "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c_2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m_2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" must be divisible by 5. Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c_2 = 5c_3, m_2 = 5m_3 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". The equation simplifies to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c_3^2 + 3 m_3 ^2 = 10137856 = 3184^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Not sure how to finish this off (elegantly)... I was thinking of sum of 2 (or 4) squares theorem, but I'm pretty sure that will fail. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Kazem Sepehrinia – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" No, we don't get Pell's equation."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We are looking to solve "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \big(N(N-1) + n\big)\big(N(N-1) - 3n\big) \; = \; q^2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" for integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n,q"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N=200"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Expanding and collecting terms, this becomes "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \big[3n + N(N-1)\big]^2 + 3q^2 \; = \; 4N^2(N-1)^2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" From this it is clear that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"q"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" must be of the same parity, so we can write "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3n + N(N-1) = 2p-q"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and rewrite the condition in the form "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{aligned} (2p-q)^2 + 3q^2 & = 4N^2(N-1)^2 \\ p^2 - pq + q^2 & = N^2(N-1)^2 \\ (p + q\omega)(p + q\omega^2) & = N^2(N-1)^2 \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" working in the Euclidean domain "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\mathbb{Z}[\omega]"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\omega"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the principal cube root of unity. Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are both irreducible in this Euclidean domain, we deduce that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N = 200"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" divides both "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"q"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and hence "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p = NP, q = NQ"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" (P + Q\omega)(P + Q\omega^2) \; = \; 199^2 \; = \; (15 + 2\omega)^2(15 + 2\omega^2)^2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" where the RHS is now a factorisation into irreducibles in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\mathbb{Z}[\omega]"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"It now follows that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P + Q\omega"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" must be equal to one of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(15 + 2\omega)^2u"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(15 + 2\omega^2)^2u"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"199u"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"u"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is one of the six units in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\mathbb{Z}[\omega]"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Running through these "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"18"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" cases, only a selection of them end up giving an integer value for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Wtthout giving the details, we obtain "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"-39000, -39800, -6000, 0, 5200"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" as the only possible values of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The way @Pi Han Goh was going with this, he would obtain an equation with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c^2 + 12m^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" equal to a particular integer. This is basically the same as the one I have analysed, with an extra factor of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to worry about."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This approach gives us a strategy for dealing with the general case of other values of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". We have to factorise "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N(N-1)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" into irreducibles in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\mathbb{Z}[\omega]"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"... "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Pi Han Goh – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" You've got a Pell equation. That opens a whole new bag of difficulties! "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Maninder Dhanauta – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" Sorry, let me start over: expand my original equation gives"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"-3n^2 - 79600n + 1584040000 = m^2"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"since we are looking for integer roots, then the quadratic discriminant of the equation above (in n) is a perfect square:"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"79600^2 - 4(-3)(1584040000 - m^2) = c^2, for some integer c"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now can you solve it from here? "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":"@Pi Han Goh"}],"attrs":[{"profile":"https://brilliant.org/profile/pi-han-0295j1/"}]},{"type":"text","text":" - I get m^2 + 3n^2 +79600n =1584040000 but how do i apply that trick to this type of equation

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Set N=  200 into (N(N-1) - 3n) ( N(N-1) + n) = m^2 for some positive integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Expand and simplify, then apply "},{"type":"text","text":"Simon's favorite factoring trick","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":".

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}
